'''Terma A/S''' is a [[Denmark|Danish]] [[Defense industry|defense]] and [[aerospace manufacturer]] for both civilian and military applications, and is owned by the Danish company Thrige Holding A/S. It is Denmark's largest company within the aerospace and defense industry employing approximately 1100 people worldwide.<ref>http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/europe/dk-industry.htm</ref>
The company was founded in 1949 by Orla and Svend Aage Jørgensen, originally making [[thermometer]]s and manometers for ships and a variety of metal components.<ref>http://top1000.borsen.dk/virksomheder/terma/organization/history</ref> The group's international customers contribute more than 87% of Terma's total sales.<ref name="computerworld">http://www.terma.com/press/news-2014/annual-report-201314/</ref><ref>http://stiften.dk/norddjurs/terma-investerer-millioner-i-grenaa</ref>
Terma A/S headquarters are located in [[Lystrup]] near [[Århus]], [[Denmark]]. In Denmark, other Terma facilities are located at [[Grenaa]] and [[Herlev]]. Terma international locations and operations include [[Leiden]] and [[Woensdrecht]] in the [[Netherlands]]; [[Darmstadt]] near [[Frankfurt]], [[Germany]]; [[Harwell]], [[UK]]; [[Singapore]], [[Abu Dhabi]], [[United Arab Emirates]] and [[New Delhi]], [[India]]. In 2004 the company opened an office in [[Warner Robins]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. Today, the company's U.S. activities also include the Terma North America Inc. headquarters in Arlington, Virginia and offices in Fort Worth, Texas and Norfolk, Virginia.<ref>http://www.terma.com/contact/locations/</ref>
==History== Terma was founded by the brothers Orla and Svend Aage Jørgensen in [[Aarhus]], Denmark where the company made thermometers and had fewer than 10 employees.<ref name="stiften.dk">{{cite web|last1=Svith|first1=Morten|title=Retsopgøret: Direktøren satsede lidt for meget på den tyske krigslykke|url=http://stiften.dk/aarhus/retsopgoeret-direktoeren-satsede-lidt-for-meget-paa-den-tyske-krigslykke|website=Stiften.dk|accessdate=29 August 2016}}</ref> In 1949 it was bought by Thorkild Juncker.<ref name="stiften.dk"/> Juncker shifted Therma A/S in the direction of electronic measuring instruments and with the employment of a Norwegian engineer soon developed a radar that would prove to be competitive in both price and quality.<ref name="stiften.dk"/> Within 6 years of buying Therma, Juncker was employing up to 120 people before his untimely death in 1955..<ref name="stiften.dk"/> It was under Juncker's ownership and management that Terma developed into the company it is today.<ref name="stiften.dk"/> Over a period of 20 years Therma A/S started developing radar- computer- and air defense systems and expanded to the European market and started producing missile systems.<ref>http://www.jernindustri.dk/smartphone/artikel/VisArtikel.aspx?SiteID=JM&Lopenr=112170001</ref> The Thomas B. Thrige foundation took over the majority of the stocks in Terma A/S in 1980. In the late 1990s Terma A/S acquired [[Computer Resources International]], a Danish aerospace and defense company as well as the Danish aircraft company Per Udsen Co. Aircraft. In 1999 the Danish [[Ørsted (satellite)|Ørsted satellite]] was successfully launched with Terma A/S being the lead supplier on the project.<ref>http://www.magnet.fsu.edu/education/tutorials/museum/oerstedsatellite.html</ref> The satellite is the only Danish satellite launched into space. During the 2000s Terma A/S made agreements with [[Lockheed Martin]] to subcontract on the Joint Strike Fighter aircraft.<ref>http://www.airforce-technology.com/news/newslockheed-contracts-terma-manufacture-parts-f35-jsf{{Unreliable source?|reason=domain on WP:BLACKLIST|date=June 2016}}</ref> Later, Terma was chosen to develop and produce several components and designs for the F-35 joint strike fighter, including the gun pod.<ref>https://www.f35.com/global/participation/denmark</ref>
==Business areas and Products== [[File:F-35A - Inauguration Towing.jpg|thumb|Terma delivers parts and technologies for the F-35 Lightning]] [[File:Rosetta - comet fly-by.jpg|thumb|The power conditioning unit and solar panels of the Rosetta spacecraft is produced by Terma]] [[File:HornsRev Blavandshuk.jpg|thumb|Terma's radar systems are used around Horns Rev wind farm to avoid the turning blades of the turbines from appearing as objects]]
The business areas of Terma can be divided into the following categories: Aerostructures, Space, Defense, and Security & Surveillance:
===Aerostructures=== Terma Aerostructures A/S is headquartered in [[Grenaa]], Denmark, focusing on design and manufacture of aerostructures for aerospace and defense companies.
Terma is involved in the development of the F-35 Lightning II, delivering a series of parts, components, and technologies to the fighter aircraft.<ref>http://www.asdnews.com/news-49766/Terma_enters_into_F-35_Long-Term_Agreement_with_BAE_Systems.htm</ref> The company delivers leading edges through Lockheed Martin, composite tail parts through BAE Systems,<ref>https://www.f35.com/news/detail/terma-enters-into-f-35-long-term-agreement-with-bae-systems</ref> gun pods for the F-35B and C versions through General Dynamics,<ref>http://www.thinkdefence.co.uk/2012/10/the-terma-f35-multi-mission-pod/</ref> as well as fuselage parts and electronics through Northrop Grumman Corporation.<ref>http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/northrop-grumman-selects-terma-as-of-denmark-for-f-35-joint-strike-fighter-program-72317557.html</ref>
===Space=== Space (SPD), providing on-board electronics and software for satellites as well as control centres. Key focus areas are [[power conditioning]] systems and [[star tracker]]s for satellites.
====Power conditioning units==== Terma delivers power conditioning systems to a series of major space products, including ESA's BepiColombo and [[Rosetta (spacecraft)|Rosetta]]. In the case of BepiColombo, the power conditioning unit is the most powerful used on missions by the ESA with a capacity of 14 kW powered by solar energy on its destination planet Mercury.<ref>http://www.esa.int/dan/ESA_in_your_country/Denmark/Dansk_stroemforsyning_skal_til_Merkur/(print)</ref>
In the Rosetta project Terma has developed a 64 square meter solar panel providing power at down to 4 percent of the Earth's solar energy and at working temperatures down to -130 degrees Celsius.<ref>http://www.denstoredanske.dk/It,_teknik_og_naturvidenskab/Astronomi/Rumfart/Satellitter_og_rumsonder/Rosetta</ref> The PCU delivers a bus power capability of 1500 watt at a weight of 8,3 kilo.<ref>Stage, Mie. "[http://ing.dk/artikel/terma-elektronik-vaekker-rumsonde-fra-aarelang-dvale-165600 Terma-elektronik vækker rumsonde fra årelang dvale]" ''[[Ingeniøren]]'', 19 January 2014.</ref><ref>Jensen, H. & Laursen, J. "[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/full/2002ESASP.502..249J Power Conditioning Unit for Rosetta/Mars Express]" Space Power, Proceedings of the Sixth European Conference held 6–10 May 2002 in Porto, Portugal. Edited by A. Wilson. European Space Agency, ESA SP-502, 2002., p.249 Bibliographic Code: 2002ESASP.502..249J</ref>
====Star trackers==== Since 1999, Terma has manufactured Star Trackers for several scientific satellite missions including [[Cryosat]] 1 and 2, [[ADM-Aeolus]], [[LISA Pathfinder]], and [[Tacsat]] 1, 2 and 4.<ref>http://digitalcommons.usu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1477&context=smallsatz</ref><ref>{{cite journal | url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S127096381100201X | doi=10.1016/j.ast.2011.12.002 | volume=24 | title=Attitude and orbit control systems for the LISA Pathfinder mission | journal=Aerospace Science and Technology | pages=283–294}}</ref><ref>https://directory.eoportal.org/web/eoportal/satellite-missions/c-missions/cryosat</ref><ref>https://directory.eoportal.org/web/eoportal/satellite-missions/a/adm-aeolus</ref>
===Defense=== Terma produces C-Flex command and control systems for war ships including ships of the Danish, Lithuanian, Romanian and Thai Navy.<ref>http://www.naval-technology.com/projects/absalon/{{Unreliable source?|reason=domain on WP:BLACKLIST|date=June 2016}}</ref> The C-Flex systems and the Terma SCANTER radar systems are supplied to new-built ships such as the [[Royal Thai Navy]] Landing Docks, the Danish [[Absalon-Class Support Ship]]s, and the Danish [[Iver Huitfeldt-class frigate]]s as well as upgrades on ships in service, such as the Danish [[Thetis-class ocean patrol vessel|Thetis-Class]] and offshore patrol vessels.<ref>http://www.strategicdefenceintelligence.com/article/BjtIHtQf7sY/2013/09/11/terma_to_deliver_scanter_4100_radar_and_c-flex_command_contr/</ref><ref>http://www.defenseworld.net/news/3575/ST_Marine_awarded_contract_to_Terma_for_C_Series_combat_system_for_Royal_Thai_Navy___s_LPD#.VD_tX9I1_Ss</ref>
The company develops electronic warfare protection systems and 3D-audio systems as upgrades for the F-16 fighters of the [[Royal Danish Air Force]]. Additionally, Terma has supplied electronic warfare solutions for the [[EPAF]] countries and the U.S. Air National Guard for F-16, A-10, Tornado and Harrier aircraft. Terma develops aircraft survivability equipment for a variety of [[Search and rescue|SAR]] and transportation helicopters,<ref>http://www.asdnews.com/news-36268/Aircraft_Survivability_Equipment_for_Polish_Mi-17_and_Mi-24_Helicopters.htm</ref> including the 14 Royal Danish Air Force [[EH-101]] Merlin helicopters in collaboration with Agusta Westland,<ref>http://www.airforce-technology.com/news/newsterma-dalo-complete-flight-test-of-rdaf-ttt-helicopter-ew-suite-in-denmark-4150291{{Unreliable source?|reason=domain on WP:BLACKLIST|date=June 2016}}</ref> and self-protection systems for the Royal Netherlands Air Force AH-64D and CH-47 Chinook helicopters.<ref>http://www.dutchdefencepress.com/?p=10651</ref> The Terma Electronic Warfare Management Systems are fielded internationally on more than 2,000 fighter and transportation aircraft and helicopters.<ref>http://cloud-computing.tmcnet.com/viewette.aspx?u=http%3a%2f%2fcloud-computing.tmcnet.com%2fnews%2f2012%2f07%2f11%2f6428936.htm</ref>
Terma A/S also produces Missile Warning Systems as an integral part of the electronic warfare solution for the F-16s of the Danish and Norwegian air forces, mounting the systems on pylons instead of the traditional fuselage installation.<ref>http://www.defencetalk.com/norway-terma-radar-warner-for-f-16s-35289/</ref>
===Security & Surveillance=== The Terma SCANTER 5202 radar is used by coast guard services including the [[U.S. Coast Guard]],<ref>http://www.gsnmagazine.com/pdfs/2013awards/GSN2013Awards.html</ref> the Spanish [[Guardia Civil]], the [[Columbian Coast Guard]], the [[Norwegian Coast Guard]], [[Port of London]], and [[Port of Hong Kong]] to track marine vessels and aircraft,<ref>http://www.homelandsecurity-technology.com/news/newscolombia-selects-scanter-radars-for-coastal-surveillance</ref><ref>http://www.defensemedianetwork.com/stories/maritime-security-2013-west-focuses-on-improving-port-and-coastal-surveillance/</ref> while the Terma ET2 embedded tracker is developed to help track stealth objects or smaller objects in the presence of clutter.<ref>http://www.homelandsecurity-technology.com/news/newsterma-unveils-et2-embedded-tracker-for-coastal-surveillance</ref>
